ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I genuinely feel that I have a solid grasp of Calc 2 after taking this course with Rachel
Mainly integration techniques, sequences and series. Was able to hone my mathematical intuition more. The course itself was quite well structured, but sometimes too fast-paced.
Calc II knowledge, integrals, series, etc...

I learned a wide range of topics in integral calculus, from Riemann sums to power series and volumes. The class was very clear about how all of these topics intersect and inform each other. I also learned how to approach problems with a more analytical eye and how to justify my work more effectively.
I furthered my math skills that I gained from high school, learning more about the "why" behind the topic of discussion in this course.
I learned a lot of math and calculus. I never took this CALC BC in high school and thought this class was very informative.
Integration, Taylor Series, Sequences and Series, Polar Coordinates and Curves, Solids of Revolution, Parametric Curves.
Exactly what the syllabus says: methods of integration, convergence tests, power series, volume of rotation, parametric equations, polar equations.
I learned a range of new calculus topics, from strategies of integration to sequences and series to solids of revolution to polar coordinates.

This course introduced me to a new way of thinking especially when it came to series and Taylor polynomials. I had seen a good amount of the material before in high school but this course really solidified my understanding of derivatives and integrals. The newer materials was series, polar coordinates, and parametric equations and Rachel did a great job at teaching it.
I learnt the essential skills necessary for calculus II
I learned a lot about the applications of integrals as well as how to solve series problems.
Problem solving skills, how to break a big problem into smaller parts and make it more approachable. Learned more about calculus and the applications of series/approximations.
Developed Calculus II knowledge and my math brain.

I gained great mathematical reasoning, abstract thinking skills and a greater understanding of calculus theory. My instructor professor diethorn did an excelent job in communicating and sharing a love and enthusiasm for calculus.
Basically BC Calculus (integration, sequences and series, parametric, and polar systems)
I am now acquainted with working with integrals, series, volumes from rotated graphs, parametric equations, and polar coordinates.
It was really hard to grasp the concepts with the amount of time given, but I will say that I did learn. I was able to grasp concepts that I wasn't able to while taking this class in high school.
Math calculus applications
Solidified my understanding of singular variable calculus.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: PROF. RACHEL DIETHORN!! She is phenomenal. She preprints packets for the class that outline exactly what we have to know with dozens of practice problems. She is prepared and goes through the packet thoroughly every class. She is also energic and genuinely cares about her students. She'll even extend office hours when we're struggling.

Strengths: I liked Rachel, I liked that there were office hours 
Weaknesses: Almost everything else. To try and understand grading was near impossible, things were graded on different scales

Strengths: Professor Diethorn's teaching was by far the biggest strength. 

Weaknesses: The course content was not always very interesting and could sometimes get confusing. The problem sets were too hard at times compared to what we had learned in class.
Course was well designed to learn in class and then practice knowledge in between classes.

This was a cumulative class in the best way possible. The topics built on each other nicely, and the progression of the class clarified misunderstandings along the way. The review materials were very helpful, and I always felt prepared for the exams. Opportunities for collaboration, however, were limited by the sheer amount of material we had to cover.

This course provided guided notes, which allowed us to not only learn the material in the best way, but also gave us the time to write our own notes upon the guided ones, which I believe was an excellent decision. Additionally, our professor was always there to assist us in our learning, and did an amazing job of facilitating this.

A huge strength of this class was my teacher Rachel and how she organized her class. I'm not sure about the entire MATH 115 department, but Rachel was an AMAZING professor, and I know I couldn't have learned as much as I did if she hadn't taught as well as she did. The lectures were extremely organized and very accessible. A weakness of this course was the disparity between sections as some of my friends have talked about how badly they think their sections are taught. Also, the tests had some poor grade distribution at times. There were questions that were worth wya more than they should've been.

I thought that the course was quite well-organized, and Prof. Diethorn was a great instructor! The problem sets and exams felt like very reasonable amounts of work, and there were lots of resources to help outside of class periods.
Rachel was incredibly organized; her packets for each class, which we would fill in with definitions and examples, were incredibly helpful!

Students' experience with this course varies highly depending on the professor. My professor, Rachel Diethorn, was wonderful and I highly recommend taking the course with her if possible. Strength: she gave us note templates for every class that she printed out but could be completed on tablets, she gave thorough review packets for every test, she was very accessible through office hours. Weakness: the curriculum is not standardized so I had friends that struggled with disorganized professors. Many friends asked for my professor's notes and some came with me to my professor's office hours.
The explorations should be allowed to be submitted afterwards

Professor Diethorn was a brilliant instructor. The course was structured and paced very well. The range of assignments, from explorations to post-class exercises to p-sets, were integral in helping me understand the material.

It took me 3 different sections before finding a prof that I enjoyed and engaged with. In every section, the person teaching it knew the material but just was not a good teacher of the material. Rachel was and that is why I enjoyed the course a lot.
The strengths include its organized structure and plentiful support from professors and tutors.

This class was very strong in its layout, material, and engagement. However, I would have liked to see more "Why does this matter" type problems. For example, real world applications of series and why they are important to learn.
Strengths was my instructor and the organization of the material.

my weakness was keeping up with the fast pace of the class. it felt as if we were learning new material up to the day of the exam or learning material on the day of the exam that did not relate to it. i felt as if this was extremely rushed.
It is a fine survey of Calculus II but is not particularly engaging.

My instructor Rachel Diethorn was absolutely the best math teacher i have ever had. Her lessons that she crafted (with note packets printed for each student) always managed to engage every student in the classroom. Everyone participated because Diethorn was intensely vibrant and uplifiting. Her lessons outlined each step and went slow enough to ensure every student was on the same page. She provided a plethora of resource material and posted the completed notes on canvas which helped immensley during finals reading week. The only weaknesss in this course was that problem sets were always due the week of midterms which made reviewing for these exams extra challenging.

Strengths: Allowed to use a cheat sheet for every exam.

Weakness: Puts a lot of weight on the exams, especially the final and doesn't allow adequate time for practicing and mastering concepts before the midterms. The professors are hit or miss in terms of their ability to explain things and their reception of questions.

I feel like the course pacing was steady and to our benefit. Psets were organized oddly in terms of use for student learning. There was somewhat of a disconnect between pset material and the lectures/exams. This made it so that I would sometimes put a lot of effort into learning something that I wouldnt be tested over, so before realizing that, Id study things that werent relevant. Pset grades also took forever to come back.

This course moves at an incredibly fast pace. I do wish that we were given time to fully digest the information. We also have little room to improve. If you bomb one test, best believe it is over for you.
Rachel was amazing

The pre-class explorations, digital note sheets, and concept checks were all very helpful to master the material. However, the "story" assignments that showed us the real world applications of the material would have been more helpful if it were presented earlier in the course.

Sometimes I found the problem sets challenging because they only used very complicated problems and didn't give me the opportunity to practice the skills I learned in class before diving into complex problems. It would be nice to have a few easy questions throughout the problems sets to help get me started.
I thought I was very well rounded in my understanding of the content. My weaknesses were sometimes rushing integral solutions because I knew them and making slight math errors.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES IF PROF RACHEL DIETHORN IS TEACHING IT!! She cares about her students, is enthusiastic, and most importantly has pre-printed packets that we go through during class which thoroughly explains the course material.

No. While Rachel was great, the class itself seemed designed to weed out people who don't want to be math majors, which was very disheartening. Some people (a lot of people) take the class to have a base for things like economics or physics, and just want to learn, not be basically told that they aren't up to par. There's very little incentive to keep doing math at this university because it's not intellectually fun, kind of depressing, and there's no way to understand how things are graded.
Yes, but really only to fulfill a requirement or if you would like to learn more calculus.
Not particularly interesting; however, I was fortunate enough to have a good professor that allowed my learning experience to be positive.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It provides a great foundation in integral calculus, and though it was one of my prerequisites, it didn't feel like that at all.
Yes!
I would if you take it with a good professor like Rachel.
I would recommend Math 115I know most people probably take it because they must, but I thought it was generally interesting, satisfying, and well-run.
If you are able to take MATH 115 (or any other class) with Rachel Diethorn, please do!! She is an incredible professor and person.
Yes. Rachel Diethorn is the best!
I would recommend Rachel!!
I would definitely recommend this course to all students who want to strengthen their calculus skills. I would specifically recommend taking it with Professor Diethorn.

Yes. A basic understanding of integrals and series is essential for any stem major. Non-stem majors looking to go into non-stem careers would not find the material applicable to their future endeavors.

Id recommend this course to any student who needs to learn calculus for any of their future courses or who is generally interested in math. The course can be quite boring otherwise. Professor Diethorn is really lovely and an excellent teacher, Id highly recommend taking it with her!
Yes! It was a great course with a great instructor!
Yes, very worthwhile and you will learn important skills outside of math that you can use elsewhere
No not really, I would tell them to take an easier course.
If needed for a pre-req then yes. Otherwise, [probably not.
I would recommend this course to another student because it really taught me to love calculus. But i would only recommend it if they were to get rachel diethorn.
Yes. I think it's probably the best course in the intro math sequence in terms of the difficulty of psets and midterms.

Yes! Youre probably taking it because you should, but this is still math that is close enough to the ground to still be applicable in life outside of the classroom. Being able to model and understand data is an important skill for everyone, and many of the concepts you deal with are important for that.
Do not take this course if you do not have to or if you do not enjoy math.
Yes
